author: By Christopher Maag and Tim Balk
title: A Rare Sighting of Northern Lights Entrances Viewers in New York Area
description: The aurora borealis, which transformed the sky with startling streaks of pink and purple, arose from a magnetic storm.
content: As a girl in Michigan, Gabriela Aguilar sometimes went looking for the northern lights in the state’s Upper Peninsula. But it wasn’t until Thursday night, when she climbed to the roof of her apartment building in Harlem, that she finally saw them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Milton Leaves Some Florida Animals in Limbo, Too
description: Florida’s animal shelters are struggling after the storm. Animal organizations are helping fly some pets to faraway shelters.
content: Hurricane Milton has displaced people all over Florida. It left thousands of shelter animals in limbo, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Nevada Asked A.I. Which Students Need Help. The Answer Caused an Outcry.
description: The new system cut the number of students deemed “at risk” in the state by 200,000, leading to tough moral and ethical questions over which children deserve extra assistance.
content: Nevada has long had the most lopsided school funding in the country. Low-income districts there have nearly 35 percent less money to spend per pupil than wealthier ones do — the largest gap of any state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Gaya Gupta
title: Friday Briefing
description: The aftermath of Hurricane Milton.
content: Hurricane Milton cut an uneven path of destruction as it tore across Florida, largely sparing the densely populated cities around Tampa Bay but spawning deadly tornadoes far from its center. At least 12 people were killed, most in the eastern part of the state. Over three million people were still without power as of late Thursday night. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
title: Israel Orders Gazans to Leave the North, but Most Are Staying Put
description: A woman in a town surrounded by Israeli troops said she and her family stayed away from the windows and prayed for relief: “That’s how we survive these dark days.”
content: For more than a year, as Israeli bombs pounded northern Gaza around Mariam Awwad’s home, she and her family of 11 have refused to leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What’s Your Favorite Hate-Watch?
description: Do you ever watch, read or listen to content that you think is bad? Why do so many of us do this?
content: Have you ever continued to watch a TV show even though you thought it was bad? Something that irritated you or made you cringe, and yet, you couldn’t turn it off?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Premier League’s Fight With Manchester City Won’t End Well for Anyone
description: A decision about rules that left both sides claiming victory revealed the broken reality of the world’s richest competition.
content: One, single, lonely thing has become abundantly clear to English soccer after a week filled with jarring acronyms and dense legalese and furious, desperate spin: Manchester City’s ongoing courtroom struggle against the Premier League is not going to conclude with either side winning. At the end of all this, everyone involved is going to lose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Wood That’s Starring in the Delacorte Theater Renovation
description: Wood from New York City water towers will be attached to the facade of the theater, where Shakespeare in the Park will return next summer.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll find out about where old wood from some apartment house water tanks is going. We’ll also find out about yet another corruption investigation involving City Hall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Reed
title: Agony, and Relief, for Island Residents Who Were Hit Hard 2 Years Ago
description: Residents of Sanibel Island, Fla., feared the worst when they evacuated to safer ground before Hurricane Milton arrived.
content: The wait to return to Sanibel Island on Thursday was agonizing for residents and business owners, many of whom were still rebuilding from Hurricane Ian in 2022 and just digging out after Hurricane Helene two weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Lynsey Chutel
title: What Is Nihon Hidankyo, the Japanese Group Awarded the Nobel Peace Prize?
description: Those who lived through the nuclear attacks of 1945 have dedicated their lives to recounting their experiences of loss and the physical and emotional toll.
content: Some 200,000 people were killed when U.S. forces dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in the summer of 1945, leveling large swaths of both Japanese cities. But many more survived, some with life-changing injuries, others bearing the terrible emotional scars of the devastation and death they had witnessed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Harris to Appear on ‘The Breakfast Club’ With Charlamagne Tha God
description: The radio show hosted by the entertainer and author has long been a venue for candidates to appeal to Black voters.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris is set to attend a town hall-style event in Detroit on Tuesday hosted by the morning radio program “The Breakfast Club,” one of the show’s hosts, Charlamagne Tha God, said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: An ‘Our Town’ for All of Us, Starring Jim Parsons
description: The Thornton Wilder classic returns to Broadway, still brutal and avant-garde after 86 years.
content: The first act of “Our Town” takes place in Grover’s Corners on May 7, 1901. Nothing much happens in the fictional New Hampshire village that day, except that two local teenagers, George Gibbs and Emily Webb, fall in love completely unaware that they do so under the shadow of the granitic pillars of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: Truly Scary Books for Halloween and Beyond
description: These terrifying tales by the likes of Stephen King and Shirley Jackson are more than good reads: They’ll freak you out, too.
content: Horror movies have a capacity to scare that seems almost unfairly powerful. Even a bad horror movie — an underwritten slasher, a lazy creature feature, a predictable serial killer thriller — can disturb you with a smash cut to gruesome violence or a montage of shocking imagery. That’s what makes horror movies, like roller coasters, so much fun: They might make you vomit, or even pass out, but it’s scarily good fun to go along for the ride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Cade Metz
title: Wall St. Profits Surge Despite Questions About the Economy
description: JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo and BlackRock reported strong quarterly results to kick off earnings season, but concerns linger about the strength of the consumer.
content: Earnings season is underway, with Wall Street giants flying out of the gate this on Friday. JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo and BlackRock have each reported results that soundly beat analysts estimates, lifting shares in premarket trading.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Blames Immigrant Surge for Housing Crisis. Most Economists Disagree.
description: The former president often implies that deportations will bring down housing costs. Reality is more complicated.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump and his running mate, Senator JD Vance, regularly blame America’s housing affordability crisis on a recent surge in immigration. They point to their plans for mass deportations of undocumented workers as part of the solution.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Everything Is Politicized’: Chris Christie on Trump, Harris and Hurricane Lies
description: How did we get here?
content: Frank Bruni, a contributing Opinion writer, talked by Zoom on Wednesday afternoon with Chris Christie, who was the Republican governor of New Jersey when Hurricane Sandy hit that state in 2012, about the differences between the political climate then and the one surrounding the devastation of Hurricanes Helene and Milton. Their conversation has been condensed and edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Scott
title: ‘Founder Mode’ Explains the Rise of Trump in Silicon Valley
description: A trendy management style called “founder mode” illustrates Silicon Valley’s growing tilt toward authoritarianism.
content: Silicon Valley’s current fascination with a trendy management meme illustrates a broader and more troubling turn in certain powerful pockets of its culture — one that has seized our politics and could even unduly influence our election (again).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: At 5:57 a.m., They Were Fighting. By 6 a.m., They Were Engaged.

content: “You look like fun,” Julie Ann Mollo wrote in her first message to her future husband. “Are you an Anthony or a Tony?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosa Lyster
title: ‘Who Is That? What’s Happening?’: Decoding the Art World at Frieze
description: The London art fair can be a bewildering spectacle, where even the insiders are sometimes scrambling to keep up.
content: Every October, one of the world’s major art fairs takes place in a huge tent on the edge of Regent’s Park. For five days, the park’s year-round population — joggers, parents pushing buggies, teenagers playing soccer — is augmented by thousands of people at Frieze London seeking an encounter with contemporary art — or at least an encounter with the contemporary art world, which is just as much of a spectacle, in its way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Trump Scaled Up His Efforts to Stoke Immigration Fears
description: Also, the Nobel Peace Prize went to Japanese atomic bomb survivors. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: At a campaign rally this afternoon in Aurora, Colo., Donald Trump depicted America as a country “occupied” by immigrants. He promised the large crowd in attendance that he would save their communities by ridding them of illegal migrants. And he unveiled a plan to deport migrants suspected of being in a gang under a 1798 law that allows for removal of people from countries that have invaded the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Choe Sang-Hun
title: A Woman Won South Korea’s First Literature Nobel. That Says a Lot.
description: While Han Kang’s victory was celebrated as a crowning cultural achievement for her country, her work also represents a form of rebellion against its culture.

source.name: The New York Times

title: Evan Gershkovich, U.S. Journalist Imprisoned in Russia, Will Publish a Memoir

content: Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal who was imprisoned in Russia for more than a year, is writing a memoir about his time in prison, his five years living in Moscow and Russia’s slide toward autocracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Stories That Changed Lives

source.name: The New York Times

title: Where Did Modern Love Come From?
description: The column’s founding editor and the former Styles editor discuss the origin of Modern Love (which wasn’t originally going to be called Modern Love).

source.name: The New York Times

title: All the Presidents’ Books: 6,500 Best Sellers and 100 Years of Jimmy Carter

title: A Democratic Boss Is in Prison. He Still Has 2 Public School Jobs.

content: Anthony Salters, the powerful and well-connected chairman of the Democratic Party in Hillside, N.J., pleaded guilty in January to federal tax fraud. Three months later, Hillside’s school district hired him for a newly created, $80,000 job teaching homebound students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: Are They Not Famous, or Are You in a Bubble?
description: A social media post about the Hollywood Reporter’s “A-List” of influencers inspired quite a few jokes online. But part of that was a misunderstanding.
content: The Hollywood Reporter announced its list of the “top 50 most influential influencers” to relatively little fanfare earlier this week. The list included names like Alix Earle, Kai Cenat and Nara Smith, as well as YouTube stalwarts like Rhett and Link and the TikTok darling Charlie D’Amelio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Missouri’s High School Athletes Can Make Money. It’s Paying Off for Mizzou.
description: A state law allowing high schoolers to earn from endorsements, if they commit to attending a public university in Missouri, has helped Mizzou attract blue-chip players.
content: In his four-year career as Missouri’s starting quarterback, Brady Cook has thrown for 7,603 yards and 43 touchdowns. He led the Tigers to a victory in last year’s Cotton Bowl. And even after an upset loss over the weekend, his team is in a position to compete for a spot in the College Football Playoff.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

title: Social Security: Why It Matters for Young People, Not Just Retirees
description: Despite fears about long-term solvency, millennials and Gen Z workers have a major stake in the program.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer, Maggie Haberman, Ryan Mac and Jonathan Swan
title: Musk Is Going All In to Elect Trump
description: Elon Musk is planting himself in Pennsylvania, has brought his brain trust to help and may even knock on doors himself.
content: In the final weeks of the presidential campaign, the richest man in the world has involved himself in the U.S. election in a manner unparalleled in modern history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: These Arizona Women Are Keeping Kamala Harris’s Hopes Alive
description: A conversation among “mom friends” in suburban Phoenix shows the depths of Donald J. Trump’s trouble with a key slice of female voters.
content: On Lisa Hoberg’s phone, the group chat with what she calls her “mom friends” is a politics-free zone. In the political hotbed of suburban Phoenix, it seemed safer that way. Why risk ruining 15 years of friendship by bringing up Donald J. Trump?
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: In Florida, Yom Kippur Services Adjust After Hurricane Milton
description: Some Rabbis are altering tradition slightly to account for dispersed congregations, power outages and flooded temples. For others, it’s business as usual.
content: The damage and displacement inflicted by Hurricane Milton has created uncertainty for Jews in Florida, many of whom evacuated and whose plans for Yom Kippur have been altered as synagogues close or adapt services. Rabbis from temples around the state are preparing for a starkly different Yom Kippur, similar to their approach after Hurricane Ian two years ago.

title: Rescuers Search for Survivors After Strikes Hit Central Beirut
description: Lebanese officials said at least 22 people were killed in an Israeli attack that reduced one of the capital city’s central intersections to a ruin.
content: Rescue workers on Friday searched for survivors after Israeli airstrikes rocked the heart of downtown Beirut overnight, killing at least 22 people and reducing one of the Lebanese capital’s central intersections to a smoldering ruin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Inside Donald Trump’s Shadow Presidency
description: In the years since he left the White House, former President Donald J. Trump has remained a force in international politics, meeting with a number of foreign leaders and operating out of his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida.
content: When Finland wanted to join NATO to ward off Russian aggression, it knew it had a friend living in the White House and could count on President Biden’s support. But to ensure that the U.S. Senate would ratify its membership bid, Finland’s government decided to also seek out the president living in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Euan Ward, Liam Stack, Ephrat Livni and Michael Levenson
title: Lebanon’s Leader Calls on U.N. for Cease-Fire Amid Search for Airstrike Survivors
description: Rescuers dug through rubble in Beirut as the caretaker prime minister implored the United Nations to adopt a resolution calling for an “immediate” truce between Israel and Hezbollah.
content: Rescuers dug through piles of rubble in central Beirut on Friday, looking for survivors and bodies, a day after deadly airstrikes in two densely populated neighborhoods of the Lebanese capital spread fear that no place in the country was safe from the Israeli military onslaught against Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Favorite Horror Movie Was a Much Scarier True Story
description: From “The Exorcist” to “The Lighthouse,” many lauded scary movies were based on terrifying true stories. Here’s what really happened.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon, Hisako Ueno and Kiuko Notoya
title: For Atomic Bomb Survivors, Nobel Peace Prize Is a Bittersweet Victory
description: Many survivors of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki attacks have dedicated their lives to campaigning for nuclear disarmament. Their mission has grown more urgent as the number of living witnesses to the bombings has dwindled.
content: Toshiyuki Mimaki was just 3 when he saw the flash from the nuclear weapon that wiped out some 100,000 lives in Hiroshima, Japan, in 1945. Nearly eight decades later, as a leader of Nihon Hidankyo, a group of fellow atomic bomb survivors that received the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday, he renewed his plea to abolish nuclear weapons.

title: Funeral Home Sent a Grandmother’s Body to the Wrong Country, Suit Claims
description: Carmen Maldonado, 96, of Queens, died on May 18. She was supposed to be buried in Ecuador, but her body was sent to Guatemala, a lawsuit contends.
content: A Queens family filed a lawsuit this week against a funeral home, accusing it of sending their loved one’s body to the wrong country, according to court records.

description: The event in Las Vegas featured emotional questions from voters on health care and the economy — and displayed the balance Kamala Harris is seeking on tough border rules and paths to citizenship.

title: Lebanon’s Prime Minister Calls for U.N. Resolution on an ‘Immediate’ Cease-Fire
description: It was the latest attempt by Najib Mikati’s embattled government to bring an end to the violence that has killed thousands and displaced nearly one million.
content: Lebanon’s caretaker prime minister, Najib Mikati, appealed to the United Nations on Friday to adopt a resolution calling for an “immediate” cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah, the latest attempt by his embattled government to bring an end to the violence in Lebanon that has killed thousands and displaced nearly one million.
source.name: The New York Times

description: The toymaker has found success in fictional films. But with “Piece by Piece,” about the life of Mr. Williams, it has gotten into a new genre.

title: A Flood of A.I. Slop + Searching for Satoshi + the Hot Mess Express Returns
description: There’s just so much slop that at a certain point it makes the internet basically useless.
content: This week, in the wake of recent natural disasters, we dig into the rise of A.I.-generated slop that’s polluting the internet and disrupting rescue efforts. Then we talk with the investigative filmmaker Cullen Hoback about his new documentary on the history of Bitcoin and about why, after so many others have failed, he thinks he has found the real Satoshi Nakamoto. And finally, we hear the train whistle approaching, and that can only mean one thing: It’s once again time to board the Hot Mess Express.

title: Trump Agrees to a ‘Women’s Issues’ Event on Fox News, but Shuns Debate

author: By Joe Klein
title: I’ve Covered Politics for 50 Years. Here’s Why So Much Hinges on Electing Kamala Harris.
description: The Democratic candidate would bring three things the country desperately needs: stability, unity and optimism.
content: In 1978, I visited my first war zone, Beirut. There were, in fact, several wars going on. The Israelis had made an incursion in the south, but there was chaos everywhere, with various local militias squaring off in the streets. Two of them had battled each other for control of the Holiday Inn. Imagine that. Beirut, clearly, had been a civilized and sophisticated city; parts of it still were — and yet it was descending into the unthinkable. The lesson was stark: My American soul, my life experience, had assumed that civilization was a rock-solid given, especially in historic cultural and commercial centers like Beirut. But it wasn’t. It was a tenuous state of grace. It needed to be nurtured, protected.

title: Nobuyo Oyama, the Japanese Voice of Doraemon, Dies at 90
description: Her alto timbre, for which she was teased as a child, and radiant laughter shaped how millions experienced the blue robot in the quintessential anime of the same name.
content: Nobuyo Oyama, the voice actress whose alto timbre and radiant laughter shaped how millions in Japan experienced Doraemon, the blue robot in the quintessential children’s anime of the same name, died on Sept. 29 in Tokyo. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Jones
title: Seven Ways to Love Better
description: Reading some 200,000 love stories has taught me a few lessons about love and life. Here are the ones that help me most.
content: Two decades ago, on Oct. 31, 2004, a short note appeared on the front page of this newspaper along with stories about Yasir Arafat’s health and the looming election between George W. Bush and John Kerry. It read: “Modern Love: Introducing a new weekly column about love and relationships. Today, Steve Friedman says he is just fine after getting dumped. Just fine. Really.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: How to Make Dinner Out of Anything in Your Pantry
description: Make those everyday staples anything but boring with these expert tips.
content: It’s coming up on five years since the pandemic lockdown instigated our collective spate of panic-buying groceries. And I’m pleased to report that I’ve finally gotten through my bulk order of canned sardines.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Stanley Tucci on His New Book, ‘What I Ate in One Year’
description: The actor and renowned foodie talks about his eating habits and his food diary, and we look at the fiction and nonfiction titles up for the National Book Award.
content: The actor-director-producer Stanley Tucci is also, famously, an avid eater, who has explored his enthusiasm for food through his travel show “Searching for Italy” and through two books: “Taste,” in 2021, and now a food diary, “What I Ate in One Year,” which will be published on Oct. 15. In this week’s episode, Tucci discusses his new book with the host Gilbert Cruz and talks about bad meals, his food idol and his path to tracking a year’s worth of eating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Many Haitians Prospered in Springfield, Ohio. Then Came the Hate.
description: A young family came to love the city where they rebuilt their lives and bought a home. Since a false rumor spread, they have scrapped outings, even to the park.
content: Sadrac and Gerda Delva found happiness again in Springfield.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen, Jamelle Bouie and Michelle Goldberg
title: The Divisions Roiling Beneath the Democratic Party’s Joyful Exterior
description: Three columnists explore what Kamala Harris’s appeal to conservatives means for the left.
content: When Democrats coalesced around Kamala Harris this summer, they set their differences aside in the interest of preventing a second Trump presidency. But at what cost?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
content: Florence Pugh and Andrew Garfield star as Almut and Tobias, a couple whose triumphs and tragedies play out over the course of three time periods in this weepy drama directed by John Crowley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: Hairballs Shed Light on Man-Eating Lions’ Menu
description: The Tsavo man-eaters terrorized railroad workers in British East Africa in the 19th century, but their tastes went well beyond human flesh.
content: In British East Africa in 1898, two lions living along the Tsavo River were hungry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Hwaida Saad and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
title: In Battered Lebanon, a Lone Gas Station Is a Lifeline in the East
description: Thousands have fled the town of Baalbek amid a barrage of Israeli airstrikes. For those who remain, Ali Jawad’s business is a critical piece of an informal safety net.
content: The gas station is nestled on the side of the road, a lone hive of liveliness in an otherwise deserted stretch of eastern Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Stranded Mariner Seemingly Floated in the Gulf for Hours After the Hurricane
description: The Coast Guard rescued a fishing boat captain Thursday afternoon and said he survived winds as fierce as 90 miles per hour.
content: The U.S. Coast Guard on Thursday rescued a man who had seemingly done the impossible: He survived for hours in the Gulf of Mexico with nothing but a life jacket and a cooler to cling to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: James Carville on Aging, Edibles and His Anxieties About Harris
description: At 79, the Democratic commentator is the subject of a documentary that captures his musings — and his warning to President Biden — about the toils of age.
content: James Carville stretched out his legs and leaned far back in his chair behind a rooftop table at the Peninsula Hotel in Beverly Hills. The Peninsula is a gathering spot for Hollywood celebrities and executives but Mr. Carville, who is neither, was the object of attention on this afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: From Wingman to Main Man
description: Wilson Payamps approached Cameron Kirk on behalf of a female friend. Lucky for him, she wasn’t Mr. Kirk’s type.
content: On a night out in July 2017, Wilson Payamps was playing wingman for a friend who thought Cameron Hall Kirk was cute. Their friend groups happened to merge at a rave at the Brooklyn Mirage, an event venue in East Williamsburg, where they were all dancing together. Mr. Payamps approached Mr. Kirk on behalf of his female friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing Will Cut 17,000 Jobs in Bid to Slash Costs
description: A new chief executive is restructuring the aerospace manufacturer, which has been losing money for several years while struggling to improve production quality.
content: Boeing’s new chief executive on Friday announced plans to reduce its work force by 10 percent, or about 17,000 jobs, as he seeks to restructure the company in an effort to slash costs and improve production of planes, which has been plagued by numerous delays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: As Trump Arrives, Aurora Insists It’s Not the ‘War Zone’ He Sees
description: The former president held rally in a Colorado city he falsely claims was overtaken by violent immigrants from Venezuela. The city’s leaders, Republicans and Democrats alike, tried to pre-emptively fact-check him.
content: Mike Coffman, the conservative Republican mayor of Aurora, Colo., had a message for former President Donald J. Trump before the Republican nominee for the White House came on Friday to a city he has repeatedly painted as having been taken over by vicious migrant street thugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Arizona Democrats Shut Down a Phoenix Campaign Office After Shootings
description: The office was hit three times after hours, once with a BB gun and twice with a firearm. No one was hurt, the authorities said.
content: The Arizona Democratic Party shut down a campaign office in suburban Phoenix after it was struck by gunfire and a BB gun on three occasions over the past month, said a local official, Lauren Kuby, on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Burtman
title: My Body Doesn’t Belong to You
description: In this essay from 2017, a young woman offers powerful testimony about the damaging effects of men’s possessiveness over women’s bodies.
content: In celebration of Modern Love’s 20th anniversary this month, we published a special package of articles about the column’s history and impact. To learn about the origin of Modern Love, read about seven ways to love better, see how the longtime illustrator creates his images, and much more, go to nytimes.com/modernlove. In this space, as each week’s Modern Love column, we are republishing four “classic” essays from earlier years that especially moved us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: A Night of Love and Mischief With Stevie Wonder
description: At 74, the singer and songwriter returns to arenas with a message of healing and understanding. He’s using trademark exuberance and joy to deliver it.
content: It was a little after 9 p.m. Thursday night at Madison Square Garden, and Stevie Wonder was finally getting loose. He’d begun “You Are the Sunshine of My Life,” one of his defining anthems, with a hopped-up-hootenanny version of the country standard “You Are My Sunshine.” He almost giggled — it was light work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Sims
title: In the Wake of Hurricane Helene, Still Saying ‘I Do’
description: Peter Batinski and Keri Terenzio, who met in April 2020, are no strangers to crisis. But the Asheville, N.C., residents couldn’t have anticipated the latest: planning a wedding with no running water.
content: On Sept. 29, in the wake of Hurricane Helene, Peter Hoffman Batinski and Justin Robbins, the brother-in-law of his fiancée, Keri Young Terenzio, went for a walk around the hard-hit Biltmore Village area of Asheville, N.C. As they surveyed the damage and checked on some friends’ businesses, Mr. Batinski noticed a man in a vest that said “media” taking photos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: In ‘The Last of the Sea Women,’ Divers Face a Vanishing Way of Life
description: The film captures the arduous work of South Korean haenyeo, who harvest seafood without diving gear, and whose traditions may be ending.
content: In the South Korean province of Jeju lives a group of women who may, at first, sound as if they’re mythical creatures. The haenyeo (“sea women”) dive and swim in the depths of the ocean without any breathing gear, harvesting seafood like conch, urchin and octopus, which they sell to support their families. Often, haenyeo are the main earners in their households. They’ve done this for centuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Aubrey Plaza’s Wilmington
description: The acerbic star of “The White Lotus” and “My Old Ass” is enthusiastic about her often-overshadowed Delaware hometown, which she calls a “magical little gem.”
content: Wilmington, Del., is often in the news as the hometown of President Biden and as a hub for corporate litigation, but it’s hardly on tourists’ radar. It has no theme park, no professional sports teams, no famous regional cuisine that demands a pilgrimage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 6 New Shows Our Theater Critics Are Talking About
description: The fall season is underway, and our reviewers think these productions are worth knowing about, even if you’re not planning to see them.
content: David Henry Hwang’s 2007 satire, directed by Leigh Silverman, arrives on Broadway starring Daniel Dae Kim as an Asian American playwright who protests yellowface casting only to inadvertently, and hilariously, cast a white actor as the Asian lead in his own play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Ta-Nehisi Coates on Israel: ‘I Felt Lied To’
description: The journalist discusses his experience visiting Israel and the West Bank.
content: In his new book of essays, “The Message,” Ta-Nehisi Coates writes about a trip he took to Israel and the West Bank in May 2023. “I felt lied to,” he told me. “I felt lied to by my craft. I felt lied to by major media organizations.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris, Elyssa Dudley, Wendy Dorr, Paula Szuchman and Rowan Niemisto
title: Why Was 1999 the Best Movie Year?
description: Wesley Morris explains.
content: The year 1999 is considered by many to be a fantastic one for movies. Some say it was, hands down, the best. It was also the year Wesley Morris began his career as a professional critic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: Personalizing a Rental Isn’t as Crazy as You Might Think
description: How else are you going to decorate with AstroTurf and plywood, or install your own ceramics studio?
content: “You don’t give up a 1,400-square-foot Upper West Side apartment,” said Tobi Wright, “not for a relationship, not for anything.” An advertising art director-turned-interior designer, Ms. Wright was speaking on the phone from the apartment in question, a 12th-floor rental in the West 100s she has occupied on and off since the age of 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Middle East Conflict Creates a Volatile Moment for Oil Markets
description: Israel and Iran are fighting at a time when prices are under pressure because of weak demand in China and concerns about oversupply.
content: The spiraling conflict between Israel and Iran has sent shock waves through the oil market, increasing prices as investors grapple with potential disruptions to the global oil supply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: In Michigan, Walz Assails Trump’s Record on Manufacturing
description: The Minnesota governor running for vice president on the Democratic ticket also had strong words for Elon Musk, the billionaire businessman who is working to get former President Donald J. Trump elected.
content: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota took the stage in a Detroit suburb on Friday to offer a sharp rebuttal to former President Donald J. Trump, who had positioned himself as a savior of the auto industry at an appearance in Detroit a day earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei, Jenna Russell and Callaghan O'Hare
title: Scared by Helene, Everyone in This Florida Beach Town Evacuated for Milton
description: Over time, the question of whether to stay or go will likely become a question of whether to keep living in coastal or low-lying areas at all.
content: Chris Miller rode out Hurricane Helene just over two weeks ago inside his picturesque yellow home across from the Gulf of Mexico in Bradenton Beach, a tiny Florida city on a barrier island. As the storm surge rose, he readied a wet suit in case he needed to escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tony Schwartz
title: I Was Trump’s Ghostwriter. A New Biopic Gets the Most Important Thing Right.
description: Critics may argue about specific factual details, but a new account of Trump’s ascent jibes with everything I saw with my own eyes.
content: “The Apprentice,” a new movie that dramatizes the early years of Donald Trump’s career, ends with a scene between Mr. Trump and an actor who plays me. The year is 1986 and I’m interviewing Mr. Trump for the first time, to begin ghostwriting “The Art of the Deal,” a book that I view today as an unintended work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukrainian Journalist Has Died in Russian Captivity, Ukraine Says
description: Viktoria Roshchina, a 27-year-old reporter, had been detained by the Russian authorities after reporting from occupied territories in Ukraine.
content: Viktoria Roshchina, a Ukrainian journalist who went missing in August 2023 while reporting from territories occupied by Moscow’s forces, has died in Russian custody, Ukrainian officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Israeli and U.S. Defense Ministers Discuss Israel’s Expanding Conflicts in Mideast
description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III spoke with his Israeli counterpart, Yoav Gallant, on Thursday, the Pentagon said.
content: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III spoke on Thursday with his Israeli counterpart, Yoav Gallant, about Israel’s expanding military operations in Lebanon, the Pentagon said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: A Choreographer’s Errands Into the Wilderness
description: The Greek-born choreographer Lenio Kaklea made her American debut at Governors Island, a fitting spot for work about the boundaries between nature and culture.
content: The choreographer Lenio Kaklea, born and raised in Greece, has made her career in France. On Saturday she made her U.S. debut on the ball fields of Governors Island in New York Harbor. This was an apt port of entry, as the work she brought — and another she presented later in the week at New York Live Arts — focused on the boundaries between nature and culture. (Both works are part of L’Alliance’s Crossing the Line Festival.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Problem With This Conspiracy Theory Is Reality
description: It’s not indoctrination that’s keeping a majority of younger voters out of the Republican column.
content: According to Tim Sheehy, the Republican nominee for the U.S. Senate in Montana, young people have been “indoctrinated” on the issue of abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Tesla Loses Court Battle in Swedish Labor Dispute
description: A district court ruled that Sweden’s constitution prevented it from taking a side in a labor dispute between Tesla and local unions that has dragged on for 11 months.
content: A district court in Sweden ruled on Friday that it could not force a local postal company to resume deliveries to Tesla that had stopped nearly a year ago as part of a wider labor dispute aimed at getting the U.S. automaker to sign a collective bargaining agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megha Rajagopalan
title: How We Investigated Political Ties to Abuse in India, and What We Found
description: Western companies such as Coca-Cola buy sugar from fields where workers suffer abuses. But the country has labor laws. Where was the government?
content: When my colleagues and I began investigating labor abuses among sugar cane cutters in the western Indian state of Maharashtra, we were startled by how open it all was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: robust
description: This word has appeared in 1,321 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word robust has appeared in 1,321 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 25 in “What to Know About New York City’s New Schools Chancellor” by Claire Fahy and Troy Closson:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Northern Lights Animate Night Skies Around the Globe
description: An outburst from elevated solar activity created conditions on Thursday that kept people’s eyes glued to evening views all over the Northern Hemisphere.
content: Night skies came aglow on Thursday with the shimmering palette of the northern lights, or the aurora borealis if you prefer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Swing State Voters: What’s in Your Mailbox?
description: Share images of your political correspondence with the On Politics newsletter.
content: If you live in one of the seven key battleground states, your mailbox is probably stuffed with political mailers from candidates up and down the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Katie Rogers
title: A Stern Obama Tells Black Men to Drop ‘Excuses’ and Support Harris
description: Before speaking at a rally for Vice President Kamala Harris in Pittsburgh, the former president spoke directly to Black male voters in an effort to bolster flagging support.
content: Former President Barack Obama traveled to Pittsburgh on Thursday to urge voters there to choose Vice President Kamala Harris in November, aiming a message at one group in particular: Black men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megha Rajagopalan and Qadri Inzamam
title: Why Politicians Ignore Abuses in India’s Sugar Industry: They Run It
description: Politicians run most of the mills in the state of Maharashtra. They deny or downplay evidence of coerced hysterectomies, debt bondage and child labor in the fields.
content: In the sweltering sugar fields of the western Indian state of Maharashtra, abusive practices such as debt bondage and child labor have long been an open secret. But in 2019, a state lawmaker named Neelam Gorhe documented a new level of brutality: Female workers were getting unnecessary hysterectomies at alarmingly high rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: When Your Partner’s Ex Is Your Biggest Fan
description: Doug Emhoff’s ex-wife is one of Kamala Harris’s most vocal supporters. Their relationship has brought new attention to blended families, but mutual admiration isn’t always a given.
content: A film producer and mother of two in California posted a short message of praise on Monday after Vice President Kamala Harris’s recent appearance on the “Call Her Daddy” podcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By W.J. Hennigan
title: An Award for the Vital Message of Nuclear Survivors
description: The Nobel Peace Prize recognized the dangerous path humanity is taking.
content: It was heartening to wake up to the news on Friday that Nihon Hidankyo, a Japanese grass-roots movement of atomic bomb survivors, won the 2024 Nobel Peace Prize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly, Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Eileen Sullivan
title: Trump Aides Sought Enhanced Security for Closing Stages of Campaign
description: Susie Wiles, a top Trump campaign adviser, was in contact with the White House chief of staff and the head of the Secret Service seeking military assets and other steps.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign has requested a series of additional security measures, including military assets, in conversations with the White House and the Secret Service because of continuing threats to his safety, according to four people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Harvey Awards Inducts 5 Comic Creators to Hall of Fame
description: The inductees are being recognized for work on G.I. Joe, Mad magazine, manga and mutants. They will be honored at New York Comic Con.
content: The annual Harvey Awards hall of fame ceremony is back next Friday at New York Comic Con, and is adding five members to its ranks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Son Has a Gambling Problem. Do I Tell His Partner?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the risks of divulging a loved one’s addiction to someone who ought to know.
content: Our 30-something son has been seriously dating a smart, capable woman for more than a year. They seem very happy; they recently moved in together and are talking about their long-term future, including the possibility of having children. She fits in well with our family and is a good influence on our son. We support them and would like to encourage their relationship, but my spouse and I are concerned about something.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: ‘Brat’ Autumn Has Begun
description: A performance and art installation by Charli XCX lured her fans out of the club and into nature.
content: Another artist might have taken the reddening leaves as a sign that her summer of fun was over. But Mother Nature’s gentle nudges were no match for Charli XCX.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: Just in time for Halloween are new scary movies about a demon daddy, evil in the woods and ’90s television hell.
content: If you watch only one new horror film this Halloween, make it this demented but deeply humane meditation on fathers and sins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Federal Judge Questions Justice Department on Boeing Guilty Plea
description: After objections from the families of the victims of the two 737 MAX plane crashes, a federal judge will rule whether to accept a plea agreement reached by the Justice Department and Boeing.
content: A federal judge in Fort Worth heard arguments Friday but withheld a ruling on whether he would accept a guilty plea by Boeing in connection to the tragic crashes of two 737 Max jets that resulted in the loss of 346 lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer and Elizabeth Bick
title: Who Said Self-Care Was for Young People?
description: How aging has affected six older Americans’ view of wellness and staying healthy.
content: “While I don’t love my wrinkles and sags, I embrace them as a life well lived,” said Evelyn Block, 76. That’s not all she’s embraced. She dyes her hair an electric blue. And her retirement hobby? She’s a roller derby referee in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Gustavo Dudamel Visits New York With Promise, and a Warning
description: The superstar conductor will take over the New York Philharmonic in 2026. Is his tour with the Los Angeles Philharmonic a preview?
content: Home is a slippery concept in classical music, a global art form of constant travel and jobs that require relocating for months or years at a time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: These ‘Saturday Night Live’ Books Bring Studio 8H to Your Living Room
description: Oral histories and rollicking memoirs by former “S.N.L.” cast members like Molly Shannon and Leslie Jones take you behind the scenes of the comedy juggernaut.
content: “Saturday Night Live,” the late-night NBC comedy-variety show now in its 50th season, generally prefers to mine its material from other people’s dramas and the conflicts of everyday American life — as it is presently doing with its weekly satires of the 2024 presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Joseph H. Reich, Charter School Pioneer, Dies at 89
description: When he and his wife opened the Beginning With Children school in Brooklyn to offer more educational opportunities to children, they set off a national trend.
content: Joseph H. Reich, a financier and philanthropist who with his wife created one of New York City’s first independently run public schools, proving that impoverished students could outperform expectations in such a setting — and which helped to kick-start the city’s charter-school movement — died on Sept. 29 at his home in Sheffield, Mass. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby McGanney Nolan
title: Take Me Into the Ballgame
description: In Kwame Alexander’s new verse novel and Karen L. Swanson’s nonfiction picture book, Black girls pursue their dreams of playing big-league baseball.
content: Baseball is America’s game, one of our most enduring and exuberant inventions. The speed and finesse of its stars have inspired generations of young people. In a pair of new books set about a century ago, baseball is thrillingly played by two Black girls pursuing their passion in the face of tremendous obstacles. Both “hold fast to dreams,” as Langston Hughes exhorted, as well as to the line drives they dive to catch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Charli XCX’s Starry ‘Brat’ Remixes, and 9 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Victoria Monét, Samara Joy, the Linda Lindas and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: For Two Years, a Scent of Love Had Lingered
description: As colleagues, Ariana Silvestro and Nicholas Kluender developed feelings for each other in 2016, but waited to pursue them.
content: Ariana Silvestro, a founder and chief executive of the fragrance company Scent Lab, spoke from the heart in 2018 when she told Nicholas Austin Kluender she thought they should revisit feelings they started exploring two years earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Is Said to Consider Brooke Rollins for White House Chief of Staff
description: Ms. Rollins, a conservative lawyer who ran domestic policy in the Trump administration, is said to be under consideration for the role should Donald J. Trump win the election.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has been privately asking confidants what they would think of his appointing his former White House domestic policy adviser, Brooke Rollins, as his chief of staff if he wins the election, according to three people with knowledge of his conversations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Scared of the Dentist? Here’s How to Cope.
description: Don’t skip appointments and risk your oral health. Try these strategies instead.
content: For Hope Alcocer, the diagnosis was grim: 11 cavities. Inflamed gums. A tooth in need of a root canal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller, Patricia Mazzei, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Christopher Flavelle
title: As Floridians Return, Officials Size Up Milton’s Uneven Trail of Destruction
description: Power outages, gas shortages and pockets of flooding were among the lingering issues. But Gov. Ron DeSantis said the damage could have been worse.
content: Florida residents on Friday returned to neighborhoods stricken by power outages and filled with piles of soggy, stinking debris as tens of thousands of emergency workers began repairing the destruction caused by Hurricane Milton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu and Dan Higgins
title: Salman Rushdie Will Testify at Trial of Man Accused of Stabbing Him
description: Hadi Matar is charged with attempted murder and assault in connection with an attack in western New York that left the author blind in one eye.
content: The author Salman Rushdie, who was stabbed and blinded in one eye two years ago by an attacker who rushed him onstage in front of hundreds of people, will testify at the man’s trial, prosecutors said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: In Texas Senate Race, Cruz and Allred Duel Over Youth Sports Without Saying ‘Trans.’
description: Ted Cruz’s re-election campaign has poured resources into attack ads that focus on transgender participation in youth sports. His Democratic opponent, Representative Colin Allred, responded with his own ad.
content: For weeks now, Texans watching television, including during prime time football games, have seen ads from the re-election campaign of Senator Ted Cruz declaring: “Boys in girls sports, that’s not right.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech, Hisako Ueno and Kiuko Notoya
title: For Atomic Bomb Survivors, a Nobel Prize and a Reckoning, 80 Years Later
description: Toshiyuki Mimaki, the chairman of Nihon Hidankyo, which was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, said his foremost wish was to “please abolish nuclear weapons while we are alive.”
content: Cities blasted to rubble. Burned bodies and flayed flesh. Invisible waves of radiation coursing through the air. And the indelible image of a mushroom cloud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Kim Jones Leaving Fendi
description: From fashion world rumor to reality, another industry shake-up.
content: The tectonic plates of the fashion world are shifting once again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,211
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Oct. 12, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: A Nebraska Senate Ad Lets One Mechanic Throw a Wrench at Another
description: Deb Fischer, the Republican incumbent, faces a stiff challenge from a union leader, Dan Osborn, running as an independent. Her latest ad calls him a “Democrat in disguise.”
content: A fund-raising PAC supporting Senator Deb Fischer, Republican of Nebraska, has been running this 30-second ad attacking her independent opponent, Dan Osborn, on television stations across the state since Wednesday at a cost of more than $372,000 so far, according to the Fischer campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Ian Willms
title: What Flying in a Wind Tunnel Reveals About Birds
description: Some birds migrate thousands of miles every autumn. How exactly do they manage it? Scientists built a flight chamber to find out.
content: It happens every fall: The days grow colder, the nights grow longer, the birds grow restless and then they take flight. In North America alone, billions of birds fly south for the winter, sometimes in enormous undulating flocks. It is one of nature’s great spectacles as well as an athletic feat: Some birds regularly migrate thousands of miles or stay aloft for days at a time.

content: No matter where they live, the beginning of a new school year is an opportunity for kids to show the world who they are and what they think looks cool right now. But how much does where you live play into personal style? To see if we could spot any patterns in what kids are wearing around the country, The New York Times for Kids visited middle schools in five different cities — Los Angeles, San Antonio, Denver, Minneapolis and New York City — on the very first day of class. Some trends were obvious: cargo pants, stacked bracelets, brightly colored hair, ’90s everything. But the biggest trend we found? Wearing whatever you like. Here, 47 kids tell us what that means to them, and what they’re into now.

content: The documentary “Super/Man: The Christopher Reeve Story” traces the life of the Juilliard-trained actor who found megastardom in the 1970s and ’80s playing Superman, and in 1995 as a different kind of hero, after an accident left him paralyzed from the neck down. It features never-before-seen footage of Reeve, who died in 2004 at 52, chronicling his early days; his pivotal friendship with his Juilliard roommate, Robin Williams; and his transformation, in a wheelchair and on a ventilator, into a leading disability and research advocate. Friends like Glenn Close, Susan Sarandon, Whoopi Goldberg and John Kerry offer their observations; disability rights activists do, too. It’s a thought-provoking tear-jerker.

author: By Laura May Todd and Danilo Scarpati
title: A Midcentury Turin Home Gets a Careful Update
description: What do you do to an apartment in a building designed by Ada Bursi, one of Italy’s first female architects? Add color and texture, but not so much as to distract from its history.
content: THE NORTHERN ITALIAN city of Turin has always embraced both high and low culture. For nearly 400 years, it was the seat of the Savoys, the royal family who ruled Italy from 1861 until 1946, when they were deposed by referendum. Their Baroque primary residence, Palazzo Reale, with its Versailles-inspired mirrored halls, still stands as a reminder of the city’s grandeur. In the 1960s, Turin was a center of the Arte Povera movement, which championed art made with commonplace materials, such as Mario Merz’s plastic-bag-and-soil igloos. It was also where the architect Ada Bursi, born in 1906 in Verona, became one of the first women in Italy to practice architecture, designing schools and public housing across the city. “[For her] beauty was not in the value of the materials — it was in how you worked with them,” says Andrea Marcante, 58, who runs the Turinese architecture studio Marcante-Testa with his longtime friend Adelaide Testa, 58. “Bursi believed in democratic luxury.”
